Friends:

California Gov. Gavin Newsom fashions himself as a climate hero and champion of the people who could harbor presidential ambitions. But as today‚Äôs featured article illustrates, Gavin‚Äôs deference to cryptocurrency interests has helped his friends and donors in Big Tech, at the expense of consumer and environmental protections.
We can only fund reporting like this because readers like you have become paid subscribers. Please consider upgrading today ‚Äî you‚Äôll score exclusive perks and support our work.

sections: This past September, California Gov. Gavin Newsom (D)

a bill that overwhelmingly passed both chambers of the California legislature and would have delivered rules and transparency to the state‚Äôs burgeoning and largely unregulated cryptocurrency industry.
The move came after the crypto industry spent more than
and representatives from the Bay Area tech giant Salesforce lobbied Newsom directly on blockchain technology and other industry matters and treated him to

This wasn‚Äôt the only time Newsom refused to crack down on crypto operations, even in the face of mounting industry scandals and imploding crypto firms. Last December, Newsom‚Äôs office published a largely glowing
on cryptocurrencies crafted mainly by tech and venture capital interests ‚Äî including several crypto companies facing lawsuits and enforcement actions.

Last month, the governor‚Äôs office did not find it necessary for anyone to attend an oversight hearing by California lawmakers on cryptocurrency‚Äôs recent effects on the state ‚Äî the same day that Newsom found the time to
attend a frothy press conference with Elon Musk
for Silicon Valley‚Äôs largest investors. He didn‚Äôt, however, disclose the fact that he and his wife, Jennifer Siebel Newsom, are both clients of Silicon Valley Bank, according to

These developments are just the latest example of how Newsom appears to be letting Big Tech and Wall Street interests dictate California‚Äôs approach to reining in cryptocurrency, at the expense of consumer protection.
Newsom, often seen as a future Democratic
, has the potential to have California set the standard on crypto regulations, much like it has done with vehicle emissions. California is the most populous state in the country, the soon-to-be
in the world, and home to more than 20 percent of all blockchain and crypto companies in North America.
Now, California Assemblymember Tim Grayson (D), author of the previously vetoed crypto bill, has proposed
to regulate the crypto industry. The bill aims to license crypto exchanges operating in California by 2025, require companies to issue financial stability reports, and ban ‚Äú

Stablecoins are a digital currency designed to have a one-to-one value with a common currency like the dollar. Unbacked stablecoins, on the other hand, rely on a convoluted system of algorithms for their value.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs clear that licensure is the next natural step for this industry, and it is equally clear that until we take that step, Californians will continue to be vulnerable to prevalent and preventable financial scams,‚Äù Grayson said in a
If the California legislature passes the bill, Newsom may again be put to the test: Will he sign a bill that offers basic consumer protection, or once again do the bidding of his friends in Big Tech?
Newsom‚Äôs office did not respond to a request for comment.

Cryptocurrencies are essentially unregulated digital money or assets that can be bought and sold on exchanges similar to virtual stock markets. Blockchains are an open source digital ledger technology used to track the cryptocurrency transactions.
The lack of regulations on crypto allows for a bevy of scams such as ‚Äú
‚Äù schemes, which involves creating excitement around a certain cryptocurrency and selling it while the prices are high
as well as the selling of blatantly

Crypto also requires a ton of electricity. Bitcoin, for example, utilizes ‚Äúproof-of-work,‚Äù a blockchain technology that uses large amounts of electricity to solve increasingly challenging math problems.
In May 2022, Newsom issued an executive order aimed to promote research into blockchains and set California crypto policy in line with a
order that sought to establish consumer protection, promote financial stability, and research the creation of a U.S.-run digital currency.

Newsom‚Äôs order directed a number of government agencies to collaborate on a report looking at the effects cryptocurrency has had on the economy and how crypto‚Äôs underlying technologies could be used by the government.
‚ÄúReally excited to see [California] taking the initiative on blockchain policy to protect consumers, provide oversight, and help grow the economy. Excited to work with @GavinNewsom on this!‚Äù
, who led the now-defunct crypto exchange FTX.
imploded within days of Newsom‚Äôs order and a crypto exchange utilized by
, released in early December, ended up being largely a spin piece for the crypto industry.

Of the 47 attendees who took part in 10 roundtable discussions for the report, only six attendees were dedicated to consumer protection, according to a list of attendees provided by California‚Äôs Dept. of Financial Protection and Innovation. Of the remaining 41 attendees, 37 came from tech, crypto, and venture capital companies.
A number of the participants represented crypto companies facing lawsuits and federal enforcement actions.
, which was fined by the Treasury Department in November 2022 for facilitating sanctions evasion;
, which the SEC charged this January for unregistered securities offerings and sales;
, which the SEC also charged with unregistered securities offerings in December 2022; and
, which collapsed on March 9 and is
allegedly facing a Justice Department investigation
due to its role in facilitating transactions between FTX and Alameda Research ‚Äî two companies run by Bankman-Fried.
Also in attendance for the roundtable discussions were
which is facing a lawsuit for making ‚Äúmaterially false and misleading statements‚Äù to its clients;
, which are facing lawsuits for security breaches; and

, which is being sued for seizing customer assets without notice. One roundtable attendee suggested California ‚Äúcan destigmatize crypto by promoting a greater understanding in the public sphere,‚Äù the report states, essentially recommending that the state help launder crypto‚Äôs poor reputation.

The resulting report briefly acknowledged the need for regulation, scams associated with cryptocurrencies, and how marginalized groups that are traditionally underserved by the banking system ‚Äúhave fallen victim to hacks, scams, fraud, and product collapses.‚Äù

But instead of detailing policy recommendations for consumer protections, the report directed California‚Äôs Department of Financial Protection and Innovation to educate Californians on how to not get scammed and train its ‚Äústaff who engage with consumers on how best to seek redress.‚Äù

Newsom‚Äôs report also acknowledged the environmental impacts associated with blockchain technology. But instead of legislative or regulatory remedies, the report simply recommended encouraging ‚Äúmore environmentally efficient blockchain technologies and environmental protections‚Äù and making consumers aware of the ‚Äúenvironmental impacts and‚Ä¶ any claims of clean energy use and carbon offsets.‚Äù

Such an approach doesn‚Äôt directly combat the massive carbon footprint of crypto‚Äôs proof-of-work processes and relies solely on the consumer‚Äôs environmental values, said Jeremy Fisher, a senior advisor at the Sierra Club, who took part in one of Newsom‚Äôs roundtable discussions.

‚ÄúI understand California is interested in not wanting to stifle innovation, but even from the parties that were part of our roundtable who are interested in innovation, they were very clear that the idea of proof-of-work‚Ä¶ was not really something that was in California‚Äôs interest,‚Äù Fisher told
Consumer advocates were disappointed in the report, arguing that innovation should not take precedence over basic protections.

‚ÄúThis is not an area where we want to be behind, this is an area where California should be leading,‚Äù said Robert Herrell, president of the Consumer Federation of California. ‚Äú[Crypto] is an industry in need of adult supervision, and right now it is not there.‚Äù
Several of the companies that took part in the crypto report have donated generously to Newsom‚Äôs political campaigns.

That included Cameron and Tyler Winklevoss, co-founders of Gemini, donated $116,000 to Newsom‚Äôs first gubernatorial run in 2018, according to state disclosures. Brad Garlinghouse, CEO of Ripple, donated $20,000 to Newsom‚Äôs 2018 campaign as well. OpenSea also donated $10,000 to Newsom‚Äôs 2022 gubernatorial run, according to state disclosures.
Newsom, in fact, has a long history of being cozy with Big Tech, dating back to his time as San Francisco‚Äôs mayor, when
at major tech conferences. Later, when he served as the state‚Äôs lieutenant governor, Newsom
in the Founders Den, a venture capitalist clubhouse in San Francisco, instead of using the state office provided for him.
‚ÄúFounders Den provides the kind of collaborative and creative atmosphere to foster new ideas not only for emerging new businesses, but government as well,‚Äù Newsom said at the time.
One of the managing partners of Founders Den contributed $12,000, the maximum amount allowed, to Newsom‚Äôs campaign for lieutenant governor,
Newsom accepted political donations in Bitcoin
during his run for lieutenant governor. The state made it an
allowing politicians to accept all cryptocurrencies as donations in 2022.

More recently, as governor, Newsom signed multiple no-bid contracts with tech and health care companies during the COVID-19 pandemic. ‚ÄúThe vast majority are Newsom supporters and donors who have contributed more than $113 million to his political campaigns and charitable causes, or to fund his policy initiatives, since his first run for statewide office in 2010,‚Äù
In 2021, the Bay Area tech behemoth Salesforce won a contract to help create MyTurn, the
website dedicated to helping Californians register for COVID-19 vaccines. It has cost the state at least
. Salesforce is run by Marc Benioff, the
On May 18, 2022, in the lead-up to the California legislature introducing the crypto regulation bill that Newsom would later veto, representatives of Salesforce
, according to state lobbying disclosures. Salesforce runs its
to digital art known as NFTs and constructing digital ‚Äúsmart contracts.‚Äù
Musk, the controversy-plagued tech magnate whom Newsom recently
for bringing Tesla‚Äôs engineering headquarters back to Silicon Valley, has donated $28,300 to Newsom‚Äôs campaign efforts since 2009, according to state disclosures.
Musk is also a crypto enthusiast
During the pandemic, he repeatedly hyped Dogecoin, a cryptocurrency
to as a ‚Äúshitcoin,‚Äù due to its over-reliance on Musk hyping the digital currency and its lack of value. Tesla
as a form of payment, but that‚Äôs more or less the extent of its use.
‚ÄúCalifornia Has Not Lived Up To Its Reputation‚Äù
Amid the crypto market‚Äôs turmoil this past summer, the California legislature
a bill that would have required cryptocurrency companies to seek licensure with the state, much like New York‚Äôs
program. The bill would have also banned unbacked stablecoins and required financial stability disclosures from companies.
In letters of opposition to the bill, the Blockchain Advocacy Coalition

that the provisions lacked clear definitions needed to prevent the potential ‚Äústifling of a nascent yet promising industry,‚Äù and that the bill ‚Äúcould be a major deterrent for smaller companies in the industry that are unable to navigate such a lengthy, cumbersome and expensive compliance process.‚Äù
Newsom seems to have agreed, vetoing the bill on September 23.

‚ÄúA more flexible approach is needed to ensure regulatory oversight can keep up with rapidly evolving technology and use cases, and is tailored with the proper tools to address trends and mitigate consumer harm,‚Äù Newsom wrote in his
, adding that it would ‚Äúpremature‚Äù to adopt a licensing structure ahead of ‚Äúforthcoming federal actions.‚Äù
Six weeks after Newsom‚Äôs veto, crypto exchange FTX began to collapse, and with it federal legislation that was largely seen as a

‚ÄúI remain frustrated by the administration‚Äôs release of the executive order and its dismissal of the legislature‚Äôs concerns, especially since those concerns have been proven correct time and again,‚Äù said California Assemblymember Tim Grayson, chair of the Assembly Banking and Finance committee, during a February oversight hearing looking into crypto‚Äôs effects on the California economy.

‚ÄúThe simple fact is California has not lived up to its reputation as a leader and we have failed to provide some basic consumer protections in this particular space,‚Äù added state Sen. Monique Lim√≥n (D), chair of the Senate Banking and Finance committee.
Now, both Grayson and Lim√≥n are the lead authors of a
that is making its way through the legislature, and both seem to be undeterred by Newsom‚Äôs lack of involvement with the legislation.

‚ÄúThe legislature has received no significant engagement on this topic, nor have we seen any crypto-specific regulations proposed,‚Äù Lim√≥n said during the hearing. ‚ÄúWhile I would have liked to have seen the governor‚Äôs office participate in this conversation, we will do our best to understand the administration‚Äôs support and approach.‚Äù
